title: 3 Perspectives on CCS
body:
Non-Governmental Organisation (BUND)

"For fossil corporations, entering a CCS economy would be very profitable. For ecosystems, health and climate, however, CCS would create incalculable risks that would span generations. Society would have to bear the consequential costs as a burden for eternity. CCS technology sets the completely wrong course. Heavy industry could continue as before instead of converting its climate-damaging production and developing sustainable products. CCS even creates additional emissions. The construction of new plants and pipelines for CCS creates long-term directional decisions that further justify and even increase the consumption of natural gas and oil. The expansion of renewable energies and an energy- and raw material-saving circular economy is thus slowed down."

Source: https://www.bund.net/klimawandel/ccs/ (translated from German)

title: 3 Perspectives on CCS
body:
Industry Actor (Saudi Aramco)

"We believe carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) will play a role in global efforts to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, while ensuring the world can continue to thrive. 

How does CCUS work?

CCUS technologies capture CO2 emissions at source or directly from the air. CO2 emissions are then transported away and stored deep underground or turned into useful products. Capturing carbon has been used for decades to help improve the quality of natural gas, but pioneering new technologies may mean we can now potentially remove and sequester CO2 permanently. Moreover, we are exploring new ways to add value to waste CO2 by turning it into marketable industrial and commercial products."

Source: https://www.aramco.com/en/sustainability/climate-change/managing-our-footprint/carbon-capture-rbon-capture-use-and-storage

title: 3 Perspectives on CCS
body:
Political Actor (European Commission)

"While CO2 emissions from fuel combustion have been declining in Europe, industries like cement, iron and steel, aluminium, pulp and paper, and refineries have inherent CO2 emissions resulting from energy-intensive industry processes. Carbon capture, use and storage can provide a key contribution to tackling these sectors’ emissions. Furthermore, it can help removing carbon from the atmosphere through carbon removals such as bio-energy carbon capture and storage (BECCS) and direct air carbon capture and storage (DACCS) and be a platform for low-carbon hydrogen production. (...) 
The Commission’s strategic long-term vision depends in part on CO2 removal techniques based on CCS: either in combination with direct air capture (DACCS) or biomass (BECCS) to achieve climate neutrality. The target of climate neutrality has been written into law by the European Climate Law (Regulation (EU) 2021/1119), which requires that Union-wide greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) and removals are balanced within the Union at the latest by 2050 and that the Union shall aim to achieve negative emissions thereafter. Furthermore, several organisations and institutions such as the Intergovernmental Panel on ClimateChange (IPCC), International Energy Agency (IEA) and National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) argue that without carbon removals it is difficult to keep the temperature levels indicated in the Paris agreement (explore the IPCC report)." 

Source: https://climate.ec.europa.eu/eu-action/carbon-capture-use-and-storage/overview_en#why-do-we-need-carbon-capture-use-and-storage

title: New Component Title
body:
The BUND is a Germen non-governmental organisation that is committed to the preservation of nature and the safeguarding of the environment. The abbrevation BUND translates to "German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation". They have about 660,000 members and are one of the largest environmental organisations in Germany.

Which of the following statements is true?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: The BUND believes that CCS would lead to a rapid transition in heavy industry towards sustainable practices and the development of eco-friendly products.
The BUND argues that CCS could lead to heavy industry maintaining its current climate-damaging production practices.
The BUND expresses concerns that CCS could create incalculable risks for ecosystems, health, and climate, lasting for generations.
As a non-governemental organisation the BUND can make political decisions in Germany.
The BUND has no financial interest in promoting CCS technologies.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

The BUND does not believe that CCS would lead to a rapid transition towards sustainable practices. Instead, they express concerns that CCS might allow heavy industry to continue its climate-damaging practices. Additionally, they also have concerns about the potential risks of CCS on ecosystems, health, and climate over the long term. Even though it is not mentioned in the text, the BUND is unlikely to have any financial interests in promoting CCS technologies.

As an NGO (non-governmental organisation), the BUND can advocate for specific policies and influence decision-making, but it doesn't make political decisions.

_incorrect.final:
You did not select all the correct answers! Let's sum it up:

The BUND does not believe that CCS would lead to a rapid transition towards sustainable practices. Instead, they express concerns that CCS might allow heavy industry to continue its climate-damaging practices. Additionally, they also have concerns about the potential risks of CCS on ecosystems, health, and climate over the long term. Even though it is not mentioned in the text, the BUND is unlikely to have any financial interests in promoting CCS technologies.

As an NGO (non-governmental organisation), the BUND can advocate for specific policies and influence decision-making, but it doesn't make political decisions.

title: New Component Title
body: The European Commission is the executive branch of the European Union (EU) and is responsible for proposing legislation, implementing decisions, and managing the day-to-day affairs of the EU. It is one of the critical institutions in the EU's complex political system. The Commission plays a central role in shaping EU policies, ensuring the implementation of common policies, and representing the EU on the global stage.
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: The European Commission highlights the importance of carbon removal techniques, including CCS, to achieve climate neutrality by 2050 and meet the targets set in the European Climate Law.
The European Commission denies the importance of carbon removal techniques in achieving climate neutrality by 2050.
The European Commission states that industries like cement, iron and steel, etc., have inherent CO2 emissions from energy-intensive processes.
In their statement the European Commission quotes many scientific publications, giving their statement higher authority.
The text does not mention any disadvantages of CCS technologies or take a critical view on them.

_feedback.correct:
Correct! 

The text does not address the disadvantages of CCS technologies or offer a critical viewpoint on them. At the same time, the European Commission references scientific publications to enhance the credibility of its statements. The Commission acknowledges inherent CO2 emissions from energy-intensive processes in the cement, iron, and steel industries. The European Commission does not deny the importance of carbon removal techniques; it underscores their significance in achieving climate neutrality by 2050.

_incorrect.final: You did not select all the correct answers! Let's sum it up: The text does not address the disadvantages of CCS technologies or offer a critical viewpoint on them. At the same time, the European Commission references scientific publications to enhance the credibility of its statements. The Commission acknowledges inherent CO2 emissions from energy-intensive processes in the cement, iron, and steel industries. The European Commission does not deny the importance of carbon removal techniques; it underscores their significance in achieving climate neutrality by 2050.

title: New Component Title
body: Saudi Aramco is a Saudi Arabian multinational petroleum and natural gas company, considered one of the largest energy companies globally. As a significant contributor to global carbon emissions, the company's role in the fossil fuel industry raises environmental alarms in the context of climate change and the global shift toward sustainable energy. Its state-owned status ties its operations closely to geopolitical considerations, potentially influencing regional stability and global energy markets. Questions about transparency and adherence to international corporate governance standards have been raised, given its state-owned nature.
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Saudi Aramco has expressed interest in and invested in carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies.
They have financial incentives to both further develop CCS technologies and to continue with producing fossil fuels.
For Saudi Aramco CCS is a way to move completely away from fossil fuels towards more sustainable, greener energy sources.
Their statement presents a very positive view on CCS technologies.
Going beyond CCS technologies, they mention the possibility of using the capture CO2 to turn them into marketable products.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Their statement reflects a notably optimistic stance on CCS technologies. Saudi Aramco has demonstrated interest in and financial investment in carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies. However, it's crucial to note that, for Saudi Aramco, the adoption of CCS signifies a partial departure from fossil fuels toward more sustainable energy alternatives. Instead, there is a dual financial motivation—driving the advancement of CCS technologies while concurrently maintaining fossil fuel production. In addition to CCS, they explore the potential of converting captured CO2 into marketable products, indicating a broader perspective on utilising captured emissions.

_incorrect.final:
You did not select all the correct answers! Let's sum it up:

Their statement reflects a notably optimistic stance on CCS technologies. Saudi Aramco has demonstrated interest in and financial investment in carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies. However, it's crucial to note that, for Saudi Aramco, the adoption of CCS signifies a partial departure from fossil fuels toward more sustainable energy alternatives. Instead, there is a dual financial motivation—driving the advancement of CCS technologies while concurrently maintaining fossil fuel production. In addition to CCS, they explore the potential of converting captured CO2 into marketable products, indicating a broader perspective on utilising captured emissions.

title: Environmental Impacts of Food and Agriculture
displayTitle: Environmental Impacts of Food and Agriculture
body:
Food and agriculture exert significant environmental impacts, contributing to deforestation, water depletion, pollution, greenhouse gas emissions, soil degradation, and biodiversity loss. Expanding agricultural activities often result in the clearance of natural habitats, leading to the decline of ecosystems. Water-intensive farming practices contribute to water scarcity, while livestock farming, in particular, generates substantial greenhouse gas emissions. Additionally, monoculture and the use of agrochemicals degrade soil quality, posing long-term threats to agricultural sustainability.

Addressing these environmental challenges is essential for fostering a more sustainable and resilient global food system.

title: Food Production and GHGs
body:
Food production is a major contributor to greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, stemming from various stages of the supply chain. Agricultural activities, such as livestock farming and rice cultivation, release methane, while the use of synthetic fertilizers and energy-intensive practices contributes to carbon dioxide emissions. Additionally, deforestation for agricultural expansion further exacerbates the carbon footprint. From cultivation and processing to transportation and waste, the entire food production system influences GHG levels.

Therefore, sustainable food production practices and reduced food waste, are crucial for mitigating the environmental impact of food production and addressing the challenges posed by climate change.

title: Resilient Food Production
body: The negative impacts of industrial farming, only heightened by global warming and pollution, have underscored the urgent need for sustainable alternatives. In this video, we will look at some resilient food production techniques. We will be centring our attention on indoor farming techniques, offering a perspective that embraces a food production approach that is both resilient and environmentally conscious.
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

title: Conclusion
body:
So, after covering three different use cases, what can we say about the importance of sustainability-related technologies? What can they do, and what can they not do?

First of all, the role of technology in driving sustainable change is undeniable. Technologies, including alternative energy sources, carbon capture and storage (CCS), and resilient food production methods, are crucial in mitigating environmental challenges. However, it's essential to recognise that technology alone cannot be the sole sustainable strategy. While it is often vital, relying solely on technological solutions oversimplifies the complex issues. here are multiple dimensions to consider, including behavioural change on individual, industry, and political levels. Politicians may favour emphasising technology's role as it offers a seemingly straightforward solution, yet a comprehensive approach involves addressing behavioural changes.

This encompasses shifts towards reduced consumption, such as the development of circular societies, where the focus lies on prolonged resource reuse. Achieving true sustainability requires a holistic perspective that combines the benefits of technology with fundamental changes in behavior across various sectors.

title: World3 Model Overview
body:
The World3 model is a computer-based simulation model used in the study presented in the book "The Limits to Growth," published in 1972 by the Club of Rome. The study aimed to explore the long-term implications of exponential growth in population, industrialisation, pollution, food production, and resource consumption. The authors of the book, Donella Meadows, Dennis Meadows, Jørgen Randers, and William W. Behrens III, used the World3 model to simulate different scenarios and assess the potential consequences of various policy choices.

In this video, we will learn more about the background of the simulation.
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

title: World3 Model Scenarios
body: The World3 model explored various scenarios to understand the potential outcomes of different policy choices and trends in human behaviour. The scenarios were based on different assumptions about the aforementioned factors, such as population growth, industrialisation, pollution control, and resource management.
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.
